1. Your full name Peter HULTGREN
2. Your address MIDDLELE, SASK.
3. Date January 10, 1963
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Johnland, Sweden
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Andreas Nilson, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) September 1903
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   To fell on a homestead and start farming at Lion as possible.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

Planning about the land, and through influence of an older brother who also took up homestead here and bought land nearby.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

To be a miner more.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I did come to Mitchell by myself, but my parents came back a few months earlier, and I built their house and it was done.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

I came in on a railroad car, bringing my family and farming supplies.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

I will remember the trip, but then we ne accident, no Indians and weekly really exciting. After people perhaps laughed at my broken English, but they were willing to do that.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

With my parents and two younger sisters.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

At Mitchell.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

The Mitchell district has been my home until now. It was nice, nice and settled in town. The next 12 years, but I am still farming at the farm I rent from my friend.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

My family knew to work needs until a new 17 years of age in South Dakota and in South Dakota, we settled here at Mitchell. Now I worked for my father for five years, and then I tried to be farming for myself.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They all considered it to be a wise move.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? I did come to Mitchell by myself, but my parents came in their own car and it was hard to drive.

13. What means of transportation did you use? I came in an immigrant railway car bringing four horses and family supplies.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) I will remember the trip, but there was no accident, just hard work and waiting really exciting. After arrival perhaps toughest at my Western English, but they were welcome to do that.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? With my parents and two younger sisters.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? At Mitchell.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. The Mitchell district has been my home district for nearly 60 years. If I am still farming at the farm I will live there.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

My parents knew how to work hard until I was 17 years of age in Mitchell. Then all of us immigrated to S. Dakota and we worked for the railroad there at Mitchell. Then I started to work for my father for five years, and then I started to be farming for myself.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Not very often.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place
    of marriage.
    Fred. The 1st of June, 1910

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?
    Not that I know of.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they
    came and where they settled.
    As stated above.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you
    would like to record?
    The cruel snowstorms and the dangers
    of getting lost on the prairie highways, etc., etc.,
    in 1937 is an example of hardship particularly to
    cattlemen as, in this case, we had a total
    crop failure and no fodder and very little
    seed for grain carried over from previous years.
    Cattle losses were sold for next to nothing, and
    cattle finally at a comparative price.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting
    friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
    I went to Medicine Hat a winter in 1907.
    In our youth time we traveled from 1910 to
    1913 visited various isolated settlements
    holding special economic promise in the
    harsh climate.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Not very often.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Fred & Edith married in 1910 at Estherville, Iowa.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Not that I know of.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.
   We settled here.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   The winter snowstorm and the damage it caused on the homestead. The severity of getting lost on the trail particularly to Cattleman's Creek. In this area, we had a little extra trouble and no facilities and very little food and water carried from previous years. However, we were able to hunt a little and survive finally at a comparative price.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)
   How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   I went to Canada as a missionary in 1907. In our first five years, we traveled extensively. In 1913 we visited various Scandinavian settlements in the holding special evangelistic services in their churches.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   In 1911 by Mr. Thompson, bought and used a Ford Coupe.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, where did you buy it? What make?
   Not until 1917 did I own a car — it was Ford.

27. Where was your trading center?
   How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing,
   better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes, but we used Mr. J. Eaton and Mr. Simpson's Catalogs mostly for clothing.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   At whatever time we felt.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   First customers had been on the increase until at present there is a growing problem.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of
   articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were
   by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the
   pioneer period.

It is hard to patronize the local merchants
and dealers as much as possible, but a
considerable purchase is made by mail.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Bell—Prairie Electric Company in 1912

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently?
   Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   At first it was a "trying it out," but at
   times went on we were satisfied to remain
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   In 1911 by Mr. Smith, who bought and used a Ford Coupe.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, where did you buy it? What make?
   Not until 1917 did I own a car—a Ford.

27. Where was your trading center?
   At Wildcat Mill from our store.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing,
   better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes, but we sold out of the T. Eaton and
   John Simpson Co. catalogue mostly for clothing.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   No particular time set.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   This occurred when they came on the new rail
   and at present there is a grading problem.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of
   articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were
   by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the
   pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Bell Telephone Company in 1912

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently?
   Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   At first it was a "trying it out," but as
   time went on we were attracted to remain.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Year moved away: 1914

Reasons:
- Poor weather conditions
- Better job opportunities in other states
- Better educational facilities
- Better healthcare facilities
- Better living conditions

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return by the 1930s?

Yes, many people moved away during the 1920s due to better job opportunities in other states. However, many returned by the 1930s due to improved living conditions.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district (build a school, organize a certain local group, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) origin and meaning of the name, (2) date of its adoption, (3) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

At the time for our district, we had a proposal to name it after our first doctor, Dr. Mitchell. His name was very popular in our district. His name was Mr. Smith. A compromise was made in using the first two letters of Mitchell and the name Smith. Mr. Smith's name was chosen because he was a doctor.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return by staying here?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district (build a school, organize a certain local group, etc.), mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School district, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in name since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

At the time for our district came to be known as Mitchell County, the name of the first farmer to settle in our district, Mr. Mitchell, was suggested. His name was Mr. Smith, a prominent man in raising the first two acres of wheat and the owner of the land. Mr. Smith had the name of the county farmer's association.
